newsitem.title: USA: INTERVIEW - Microsoft deal to close soon.
newsitem.headline: INTERVIEW - Microsoft deal to close soon.

text.p: Microsoft Corp's planned purchase of about 12 percent of Comcast Corp for $1 billion is expected to close in "weeks, not longer," an executive of the software giant said Monday.
Greg Maffei, vice president for corporate development, said no federal antitrust approval is required because Microsoft is not buying voting shares of the cable television company.
Comcast President Brian Roberts said in the joint telephone interview that the investment by Microsoft would accelerate the company's deployment of digital television and cable computer modems.
He also said the company would use the cash to pay off debt and buy back stock, although he was not specific.
"We weren't out looking to raise capital," he said. "It's more of an opportunistic situation. We're not going to change our strategy."
The investment gives Microsoft the right to a seat on Comcast's board, but for now the software giant will post only an "observer," Maffei said.

Microsoft and its chairman Bill Gates also will offer "guidance" to Comcast in its deployment of new technologies such as cable modems from At Home Corp ATHM.O, in which Comcast holds a stake, Maffei said.
"Bill Gates is going to be working with Brian to make sure that what they're doing technologically and strategically makes sense for the long haul," he said.
In a separate interview, Microsoft senior vice president Craig Mundie said the investment was a "natural outgrowth" of discussions between Gates and Roberts over the past two months.

He said Comcast is a significant Microsoft customer as a user of the Windows NT operating system and Internet server software. And almost all of Comcast's cable television systems carry MSNBC, the all-news channel jointly owned by Microsoft and General Electric Co's NBC network, he said.
Mundie said he expects the future of television to evolve around three different products, beginning with traditional television sets with improved pictures and sound.
Next will be "hybrid television programming," with standard television programming "wrapped" by related data from the Internet.
Finally Mundie sees an advanced form of the service offered by Web TV, which Microsoft is in the process of buying, that offers Internet access using a television set-top box.
